messageBody:
>So said james_khu on 4/21/2003 --------------------

>Before, I was looking for a quick solution, by trying to look for
>hands on tutorial which explains about EJB as well as the testing
>itself. I guess there's no such thing out there.

Testing is not factory work. There is no ten-step guide to testing with EJBs. In fact, testing with EJBs -- really doing good Programmer Testing -- is no different from testing code that lives in any other framework. There are a number of approaches, and the suggestions I have for you depend on your approach. That's why I asked you a question.

Seeing as you're supposedly doing research at the graduate level, I assumed that you were both capable and willing to think for yourself a little. Google is not some oracle that knows all.

>However, I must say this. I am really disappointed at some of the
>replies out there which really don't address the real question.
<snip />

When you ask skilled people in their area a question and they give you a strange answer, you could begin by assuming that they have a purpose to that answer. I'm not saying that every answer you got was a good one -- frankly, that doesn't concern me -- but did you think about what I asked you at all? If you did, then what did you come up with? What kind of testing are you trying to do? What is it that you're trying to verify?

1. The business logic in your EJBs?
2. The way you connect your business logic into the EJB framework?
3. Your EJB/RDB mapping for a CMP entity bean?
4. Your EJB lifecycle methods?

I would suggest different approaches -- and tools -- for each. #1 requires some deft refactoring work, #2 and #3 probably require connecting to the container and #4 is dead straight-forward "plain old Java object" testing.

As you can see, "Testing EJBs" is really not enough information for me to point you in what I think is the right direction.

Still think it was a useless and irrelevant answer?

>Anyway, I am just expressing myself, and I hope that I don't offend,
>or tick off anyone. I totally appreciate the time you guys took to
>reply to my message.

Your comments, though, lead me to believe that my assumption was faulty: that you are not interested in thinking about the problem. Instead, you just want to be told what 14 steps to follow to get a result. I realize that I never finished a Master's Degree, but when I was there and working on it, I was responsible for thinking through problems and grappling with questions.

Maybe I've gone too far, here, but I'm just expressing myself. :)
